basics.name: Daniel Manrique-Castano
basics.label: Neuroscientists / Data scientist
basics.summary: I am a neuroscientist focused on understanding glial reactivity following brain injury. To address these issues, I rely on image processing tools and statistical modeling using Python and R. I am an ardent advocate for open and reproducible science, and a dedcitaed educator in good research practices and research data managemen. Science communication and my recent foray into project management complement my skill set.

work.name: Univeristy Laval, Quebec, Canada
work.summary: Research on pericyte reactivity and brain remodeling following cerebral ischemia
highlights: Pericyte reactivity following ischeia, Point pattern analysis, Topological data analysis

work.name: Universidad San Buenaventura, Bogotá, Colombia
work.summary: Lecturer in the PhD program in Applied Neuroscience and Behavior. Research design, research data management, data analysis, scientific writing

work.name: Essen University Hospital, Essen, Germany
work.summary: Research on extracellular matrix, neuroglial and immune response in mouse model of cerebral ischemia
highlights: Neuroglial reactivity following ischeia, Extracellular matrix

work.name: Pontificia Universidad Javeriana, Cali, Colombia
work.summary: Research on cortical and transcallosal neurCerebral ischemia

work.name: Hospital Departamental del Valle, Cali, Colombia
work.summary: Neuropsychological assessment to hospitalized and outpatients in the neurosurgery unit

education.institution: International Graduate School of Neuroscience, Ruhr Univeristy Bochum

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).
